properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The sunny and very dry weather, unstable spring air and light winds could lead to the development of dust devils over these regions this afternoon. Dust devils are rapidly rotating columns of air that pick up dust. These columns can be up to a few dozens metres in diameter and come with gusts of more than 80 km/h. These gusts could propel unsecured objects, damage weak buildings and cause injuries. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-14T22:00:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-14T14:10:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0843673413.2020
Area: Mont-Laurier area, La Minerve - Rouge River area, Saint-Michel-des-Saints area, Saint-Donat - Mont-Tremblant Park area, Matawin - Mauricie National Park area, Lac-aux-Sables area, Shawinigan area, Gouin Reservoir area, Parent area, Ashuapmushuan Wildlife Reserve area, Normandin - Péribonka area, Alma - Desbiens area, Saint-Félicien - Roberval area, Lake Bouchette area, La Tuque area, Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area, Forestville area, Les Escoumins area, Falardeau - Mont-Valin area, Sainte-Rose-du-Nord area, Ville de Saguenay area, Rivière-Éternité - Petit-Saguenay area, Tadoussac - Baie-Sainte-Catherine area, Rimouski Wildlife Reserve area, Amqui area, Matapédia area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Minganie, Témiscouata
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. The ground, already near saturation, has little ability to absorb further rainfall. A low pressure system moving northwards across Alberta will spread rain to the Fort Nelson and Muncho Lake - Stone Mountain Park regions today. Rain heavy at times has started in Fort Nelson and will spread to the Rockies this afternoon. The rain will persist through Monday. Total rainfall amounts of 50 to 90 mm can be expected by Monday evening. Given the wet antecedent conditions in the region this past month (including a similar weather system last weekend), the ground is already saturated in many areas. The prolonged moderate to heavy rainfall may result in higher overland runoff. Flood warnings and advisories from the BC River Forecast Centre can be found at: http://bcrfc.env.gov.bc.ca/warnings/index.htm . ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-15T09:37:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-14T17:38:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0411520568.2020
Area: Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An unseasonably cool airmass has resulted in wet snow occurring near the summit of the Okanagan Connector this morning. Snowfall accumulations of 2 to 5 cm are possible before the snow changes to rain by this afternoon. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-15T01:04:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-14T12:03:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4182613182.2020
Area: Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Funnel clouds are also possible. The risk of severe weather will last until later in the evening. ### Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-15T07:59:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-14T18:43:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2941712700.2020

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Minimum temperatures: 0 to +4 (coolest in low lying areas). Locations: northern New Brunswick. Time span: early Monday morning. Remarks: Patchy frost is expected to form as clearing skies and light winds coincide with cool temperatures, especially in low lying areas. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-15T05:49:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-14T13:50:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4079869746.2020
Area: Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway, Bathurst and Chaleur Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Some plants may be damaged or even destroyed by frost. Patchy frost is likely tonight into Monday morning as ground temperatures fall to near the freezing mark. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-06-15T06:33:17-00:00
